awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) operates R/V Sikuliaq, a 261-foot, global class ice-capable oceanographic research vessel owned by the NSF as part of the UNOLS fleet. Sikuliaq provides a general-purpose platform for multidisciplinary research missions from polar to temperate latitudes. The ship was delivered in 2014 and has completed four years of funded operations. UAF requests funds to purchase and install shipboard scientific support equipment that would be custom engineered to enhance the vessel's capability in support of NSF-sponsored research to be undertaken on Sikuliaq in the future.

In 2018, R/V Sikuliaq completed 232 days, 142 (62%) of which were for NSF. In 2019, the vessel is scheduled to sail 252 days with 69% (174 days) of the schedule for NSF.  With this proposal, UAF provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment:

1)	IP radio system	$20,382	
2)	Traction winch sheaves	$37,440	
3)	Hanging blocks	$44,900	
4)	Air compressor	$17,155	
			$119,877	


Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
IP Radios

Sikuliaq invested in ICOM’s IP radio technology, also known as Radio over IP (RoIP). The idea was that we could address the UHF dead zones on the ship by leveraging the vessel’s science network and Wifi Access Points (WAPs). We carried out a wireless coverage survey throughout the ship, and added more WAPs as needed in machinery spaces, etc. Sikuliaq now has 27 WAPs in total, three of them ruggedized for outdoor use to cover the weather decks. In 2020, we purchased ICOM’s VE-PG4 RoIP Gateway, which allowed us to bridge UHF radio frequencies via dedicated basestations with the IP-based digital radio channels. This seemed like the ultimate solution for handheld radio communication around the ship, where crew and scientists could utilize either type of radio interchangeably, yet communicate with each other over the same spectrum. As we started utilizing the radios for operations, we discovered a drawback. The wifi chips in the IP radios were not capable of seamlessly roaming between WAPs as a person moved between spaces. There are various wireless protocols under 802.11, some of them pertaining to the ability to roam seamlessly. Even though they use the nearest WAP with the best signal strength, these devices also keep track of what other WAPs are nearby, ready to switch at a moment’s notice. It has become an innate expectation to communicate over radio while moving between different spaces throughout the ship. Ultimately, we did not adapt the IP radios as the primary means of ship-based communication. The infrastructure is in place and crew/scientists still use them all the time, but they cannot be relied on for critical operations, so we continue to invest in UHF radios.

Traction Winch Shells

The new set of traction winch shells have been installed for over a year and a half now, and this upgrade can be considered another substantial success in improving the traction winch system aboard Sikuliaq. We no longer have to worry about our wires stretching or becoming slack between the two warping heads. The shells are now optimized for the general range of pull force based on the safe working loads of the tension members in use on the storage drums, rather than optimizing for the pull capability of the machinery. It’s one of those things where no one onboard talks about it anymore because there is no longer an issue, and things are working as one would expect they should with properly designed overside handling gear. In addition, with the upgrade of one of the storage drums, which now houses a 10 km length of .681 power optic cable, we have fully completed our conversion to proper handling of large-diameter electro-optical tension members throughout the entire system, including all sheaves and blocks in the overboarding wire path.

Hanging Blocks

We are quite happy with the new Smith-Berger hanging blocks. It took no time at all for the smaller of the two blocks (36N-HB model) to become the ship’s workhorse hanging block for doing large-diameter cable operations off the A-frame. The ship’s 9/16”trawl wire has been used numerous times with this block for overboarding operations such as gravity coring, multicoring, and dragging operations. The wide mouth makes it conducive for pulling hardware through, and having the sheave recess into the cheek plates makes it virtually impossible to get wire or lines snagged. We have yet to use the 48” block, since Sikuliaq has not been scheduled with a cruise that has requested to run the .681 power optic cable or trawl wire at a low safety factor. This has much to do with the COVID impacts, as very few cruises were carried out in the second half of 2020.

Ship’s Service Compressed Air

The installation was carried out during the 2021 winter maintenance period while Sikuliaq was dockside at the UW pier. A new Quincy air compressor was installed as an additional Ship’s Service Air Compressor. The ship’s crew fabricated the foundations for both the receiver and compressor. They also designed, sourced, and installed the power supply with control wiring. Snow Boatbuilding was contracted to do the welding and pipe fitting in order to connect the new receiver to the ship’s service system. This incorporated several other parts and fittings such as valves and pressure reducing stations. The overall design of the system is such that this new auxiliary air compressor can take the load off the other existing compressors. A flex hose connection was the final part needed, and by early spring the compressor and receiver were put into full operation. This expansion to Ship’s Service Air has substantially increased our pneumatic air capability on deck and throughout the ship, so now we can run multiple pneumatic tools, air tuggers, and hoists simultaneously, while being able to meet CFM demands.


Last Modified: 09/29/2021
Modified by: Ethan Roth

IP Radios

Sikuliaq invested in ICOM’s IP radio technology, also known as Radio over IP (RoIP). The idea was that we could address the UHF dead zones on the ship by leveraging the vessel’s science network and Wifi Access Points (WAPs). We carried out a wireless coverage survey throughout the ship, and added more WAPs as needed in machinery spaces, etc. Sikuliaq now has 27 WAPs in total, three of them ruggedized for outdoor use to cover the weather decks. In 2020, we purchased ICOM’s VE-PG4 RoIP Gateway, which allowed us to bridge UHF radio frequencies via dedicated basestations with the IP-based digital radio channels. This seemed like the ultimate solution for handheld radio communication around the ship, where crew and scientists could utilize either type of radio interchangeably, yet communicate with each other over the same spectrum. As we started utilizing the radios for operations, we discovered a drawback. The wifi chips in the IP radios were not capable of seamlessly roaming between WAPs as a person moved between spaces. Even though they use the nearest WAP with the best signal strength, these devices also keep track of what other WAPs are nearby, ready to switch at a moment’s notice. Ultimately, we did not adapt the IP radios as the primary means of ship-based communication. The infrastructure is in place and crew/scientists still use them all the time, but they cannot be relied on for critical operations, so we continue to invest in UHF radios.

The new set of traction winch shells have been installed for over a year and a half now, and this upgrade can be considered another substantial success in improving the traction winch system aboard Sikuliaq. We no longer have to worry about our wires stretching or becoming slack between the two warping heads.
